manufacturerProductDescription.media_text: A colorful and eclectic comic anthology of autistic experiences from creators with autism organized by Bex Ollerton. 30 autistic creators contributed to this anthology, touching on topics such as masking, self-diagnosis, and autistic joy!
Masking and Mirroring by Bex Ollerton Compliments by Kayla Gilliam Tips for Autistic Adult Life by T Catt
Autistic Burnout by Dominique Morris Autistic Joy by Taylor Reynolds Community: On Autism, Race, and Representation by Alicia Wedderburn-Graham and Micaela Wainstein

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars High Interest for Older Children
reviews.reviewText: Excellent graphic novel for older children and teens to understand autism in an engaging way. Interesting for adults too! My child chose it for summer reading.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 10, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Powerful book centering autistic lived experience
reviews.reviewText: I don't know of any other books like this! It is graphic form, short vignettes on personal lived experience of autistic people dealing with issues such as gender identity, ableism, masking to fit in and the costs of that, being misunderstood, reconnecting with neurodivergent identity and being unapologetically autistic, advocacy and self-actuallization...it's all there!! I am the parent of an autistic teen and while I couldn't get her to read all of it (she is allergic to any of my recs, LOL), I sent her pics of ones I thought she would definitely relate to and she was definitely surprised to see someone get it right...we need more books like this. Second series please!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great art, and the importance of the challenges and understanding.
reviews.reviewText: excellent book especially for younger friends and families dealing with these issues.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 2, 2023
Reviewed in the United States on October 21, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars A great graphic novel about autism
reviews.reviewText: 4 stars - It was really goodThis was a great anthology of comics about autism. There are over 30 autistic artists that participated in this anthology and each presented an emotional and impactful comic. I loved the variety of artistic styles presented in this collection.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 14, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Get a firsthand look at life on the spectrum through an awesome comic anthology.
reviews.reviewText: Great book for gaining a better understanding about life on the spectrum through the eyes from those on the spectrum. Wonderfully written and drawn with such brilliant diverse talent.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on March 19, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars My teenage brother loves this

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2024
reviews.reviewText: First off, I'm definitely buying a physical copy of this book when it comes out. I have a similar compendium of gay comics and this compendium of autistic comics is its perfect twin. While I don't have the diagnosis, I strongly identify with pretty much all the experiences, concepts, and behaviors expressed in this book. I was so delighted to learn that how self-diagnosis is accepted by most of the community...and horrified to learn about the origins of "Asperger's"! I found the Tips for Autistic Adult Life to be very helpful, and the concept of Autistic Burnout to be the best description and explanation of my sensory overload tantrums. I'm amazed at how one book has managed to be entertaining, humorous, cute, informative, and inspiring all at once. I can only hope this book will be as interesting to allistic readers as it is to the autistic community!

reviews.reviewTitle: Thank you for making this book
reviews.reviewText: My daughter loves this book. It also helped me. Both of my kids, boy and a girl, are on the spectrum ... as a parent you sometimes don't understand your kid ... and visual art - comic - is such a fine way to translate feelings and thoughts into life ...Seeing first hand, that you're not alone in this.So ... Bex Ollerton - thank you. :)

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 23, 2023
reviews.reviewText: It’s a brilliant collection of short comics about autism, from autistic creators sharing their everyday experiences of being autistic. My 9 year old instantly recognised herself in one of the comics and was eager to read about and from people who are also on the spectrum.I highly recommend this book for kids and adults alike.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 9, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to read for us autists who cant pay attention to books
reviews.reviewText: I love this comic, its just what i wanted when i was looking for an autism book.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 28, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: By Autistic people, for autistic people
reviews.reviewText: It's so great to have a book like this to read and learn more about your diagnosis and feel so much more relief as you find out how common some of the things you do that were previously seen as "weird". Highly recommend if you are autistic or just want to learn more about autism.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on December 10, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: Creative, engaging and honest - a beautiful representation autistic people
reviews.reviewText: Amazing collection of comics of all different styles, which in itself is a brilliant display of the variety of autistic people out there. Beautifully crafted, displaying the joys of being autistic as well as the struggles in a very accessible medium. A must read for autistics and non autistics alike!
